title-group.article-title: Pandemic planning for primary care in Southwestern Ontario: protocol for a sequential multiple-methods design

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Family Medicine, Schulich School of Medicine & Dentistry, Western University, London, Ontario, Canada
2Faculty of Health Sciences, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada
3Faculty of Nursing, Memorial University of Newfoundland, St. John’s, Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: During the COVID-19 pandemic, primary care providers rapidly adapted their practice in response to emerging knowledge of infection risk, resource availability and evolving patient and system needs. Given the previous lack of guidance specific to primary care settings, there is a need to formalise and integrate lessons learnt from these successful adaptations into future pandemic plans. Our project will develop a model for pandemic planning in primary care designed for replication in other Canadian regions and internationally to facilitate the scale and spread of effective primary care pandemic response strategies.

sec.title: Methods and analysis
sec.p: We will apply a pragmatic approach and a sequential multiple-methods design consisting of three objectives: (1) scoping review, (2) priority setting exercise and (3) plan creation. For objective 1, we will conduct a scoping review to identify the essential supports of a pandemic response plan for primary care at the clinic, community, regional and provincial levels in Canada and comparable countries. We will conduct the review in accordance with the Joanna Briggs Institute methodology (search date July 2025) and synthesise findings based on recurring themes. For objective 2, we will engage primary care providers, public health professionals and health system managers in a priority-setting exercise consisting of deliberative dialogues and a Delphi process. The exercise will involve a presentation and three rounds of online surveys asking participants to rank the importance of various pandemic supports for primary care. We estimate that 100 participants will attend the presentations and 60 will complete all three rounds of the survey. For objective 3, we will co-create clinic-level, community-level and region-level pandemic response plans in Southwestern Ontario through working groups led by primary care providers and public health members of the research team, with an aim to engage approximately 12–24 participants. We will use rapid reviews, stakeholder input and evidence gathered in earlier components of the project to operationalise prioritised supports.

sec.title: Ethics and dissemination
sec.p: We obtained ethics approval from the Western University Research Ethics Board (project ID: 127132) and will use best practices for promoting consent, confidentiality and data security. We will disseminate findings through regional, national and international conferences, peer-reviewed journal publications and online platforms. Lastly, we will develop and share a toolkit for pandemic planning in primary care to encourage further research and inform future pandemic preparedness efforts.

caption.title: STRENGTHS AND LIMITATIONS OF THIS STUDY

list-item.p: Our methodology prioritises the incorporation of equity into pandemic preparedness planning, ensuring that input is gathered from individuals with lived experience so that the needs of marginalised and vulnerable groups are addressed.

The study uses a nested logic model, allowing for a structured synthesis of findings and ensuring that pandemic response planning considers interdependencies between clinic, community, regional and provincial levels.
The use of a Delphi methodology with multiple rounds supports iterative stakeholder engagement and consensus-building towards priority supports.
In accordance with scoping review methodology, no formal critical appraisal of included studies is conducted, which limits the ability to assess the quality of evidence collected.
The sample of participants in the priority setting exercise is regionally limited to Middlesex-London, which may reduce generalisability of priority supports to other regions or jurisdictions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: An effective primary care pandemic response is essential to protecting population health, maintaining the functioning of the broader health system and safeguarding the well-being of primary care providers. Primary care providers, including family physicians (FPs) and primary care nurses (PCNs; ie, nurse practitioners, registered nurses and registered/licensed practical nurses), play critical roles in pandemic response and are often the first point of contact in community-based outbreaks, encountering new diseases when little is known about the transmission, symptoms or treatment.1 2 They frequently work across multiple settings3 and care for medically vulnerable patients while mitigating transmission risks.415 Despite this, there were limited references to primary care in the Canadian federal and provincial pandemic planning documents published prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as within international pandemic response plans.1624 The lack of existing guidance documents resulted in primary care providers feeling inadequately prepared and supported throughout the pandemic.4625 This gap has been linked to provider burnout3340 and perceptions that primary care is undervalued within the healthcare system.5 29 33 The lack of primary care-specific pandemic planning contributed to a backlog of patients seeking preventive and mental healthcare services3437 and exacerbated primary care provider shortages, as increasing numbers of FPs are leaving the workforce.38 These challenges are further compounded by the declining number of medical students choosing to train as FPs in Canada,39 40 as well as the growing trend of FPs moving away from longitudinal, comprehensive family medicine.41

Primary care has distinct attributes that necessitate tailored pandemic preparedness plans; however, several factors make planning and coordination in primary care particularly challenging. For example, many family practices in Canada operate as private small businesses,4244 which can complicate efforts to communicate and coordinate responses. Research has demonstrated that during the COVID-19 pandemic, primary care providers with links to regional organisations—through academic affiliations and/or hospital privileges—had better access to information on pandemic-related operational matters.515 2528 31 45 Given that primary care providers are a trusted source of information for patients,284648 it is critical that they receive coordinated and timely access to information, including advance warning of the broader pandemic response plan and their role in it, and sufficient time and guidance to interpret, apply and disseminate public health directives to their patients. To address this, a number of studies have highlighted the need to develop communication plans and infrastructure to inform and engage with primary care providers in community-based practices who may not have links to regional organisations during rapidly evolving health crises.32 49 For example, relatively simple measures such as email lists can facilitate communication.5 27 28 32 As independent entities, community-based primary care practices may also require assistance in securing essential resources, such as personal protective equipment (PPE), especially when demand surges.5052 Successful pandemic responses, including infection prevention and control, screening, testing and vaccination, require integrated coordination among clinics, communities, public health and the broader health system.46 53 54

sec.title: Rationale
sec.p: Over the course of the COVID-19 pandemic, primary care providers rapidly adapted their practices in response to emerging knowledge of infection risk, resource availability and evolving patient and system needs.75558 As attention to pandemic measures wanes, there is a risk of losing the ‘collective institutional memory’ of these successful adaptations. Therefore, this project will address a pressing need to formalise and integrate the lessons learnt from the COVID-19 pandemic response into future pandemic preparedness planning. Using a sequential multiple-methods approach, the study will develop a model for pandemic planning in primary care designed for replication in other regions across Canada and internationally. The project will generate high-quality evidence and practical tools to support pandemic planning efforts in other jurisdictions, facilitating the scale and spread of effective primary care pandemic response strategies.

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: The goal of this project is to identify the key elements of an effective pandemic response plan for primary care and examine the facilitators and barriers to its implementation. For this project, we will address the following research objectives:

list-item.p: Identify and map the essential supports of a pandemic response plan for primary care at the clinic, community, regional and provincial levels, based on the literature (scoping review and synthesis).
Develop a list of priority supports to include in clinic-level, community-level and region-level pandemic response plans (priority setting exercise).
Develop clinic-level, community-level and region-level pandemic response plans for primary care (plan creation).

sec.p: By priority supports, we refer to the policy instruments and infrastructure required by primary care providers to perform pandemic roles. Specifically, we will focus on supports that use exhortation (ie, information) policies, as these will be easier to create than supports that require new infrastructure or expenditure policies, particularly at the provincial level.

sec.title: Overall study design
sec.p: This project is grounded in an integrated knowledge translation (iKT) model59 and builds on two completed projects. The first project (hereafter referred to as ‘3PC’) consisted of a multiple case study of regions in four Canadian provinces (British Columbia, Ontario, Nova Scotia and Newfoundland and Labrador) and involved a chronology of FP roles in the COVID-19 pandemic response, a provincial policy analysis and qualitative interviews with FPs who were practising during the pandemic.10 The second project (hereafter referred to as ‘3PC-N’) replicated this methodology while expanding the focus to integrate PCN perspectives. Both projects represent the knowledge inquiry phase of the knowledge creation cycle; the current project reflects transitions to ‘synthesis’ and ‘tools production’ in the cycle.59

For this project, we will use a pragmatic approach6062 and a sequential multiple-methods design consisting of three objectives: (1) scoping review, (2) priority setting exercise and (3) plan creation. Pragmatism is focused on finding solutions to practical or real-world problems and is characterised by a mix of multipronged quantitative and qualitative methods chosen to best address the problem.61 We will use a nested logic model63 to organise findings from the literature and conceptualise pandemic plans for primary care (figure 1). Logic models are visual representations that depict the relationship between programmatic elements and can be useful in programme planning and implementation.63 Components of logic models vary; the logic model for this project consists of (in program logic terminology) the situation or context, inputs, activities, assumptions and external factors. The nested nature of the logic model represents the dependence of clinic-level supports on supports available at clinic, community, regional and/or provincial levels and speaks to the need to integrate plans across these same levels.272943 64

caption.title: Logic model of pandemic response plans for primary care.63

sec.title: Proposed timeline
sec.p: We anticipate completing the final steps of the scoping review (objective 1), including data extraction, analysis and synthesis by August 2025. For objective 2, survey pre-testing will take place between August and October 2025, followed by three rounds of the Delphi process to take place from October 2025 to January 2026. Final analysis and write-up of the Delphi results are expected to be completed by June 2026.

sec.title: Approach
sec.p: We will conduct a scoping review to identify the essential supports of a pandemic response plan for primary care at the clinic, community, regional and provincial levels in Canada and other comparable countries (ie, Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) member countries).65 We will conduct the scoping review in accordance with the Joanna Briggs Institute (JBI) methodology for scoping reviews66 and report study findings in line with the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR).67 We will use the review to identify policies and/or procedures that support primary care providers in carrying out pandemic-related roles, including the provision of routine primary care.

sec.title: Research questions
sec.p: The scoping review will focus on three key research questions: What are the supports that help primary care providers carry out pandemic roles? At what level (ie, clinic, community, region or province) are these supports available? What methods (ie, interviews, administrative data, surveys, etc) were used to identify the supports?

sec.title: Inclusion criteria
sec.p: To be included in this review, studies must examine primary care providers (ie, FPs/general practitioners and/or PCNs). To ensure we are accurately identifying primary care provider titles across the international literature that are relevant to the Canadian context, we will refer to a recent document analysis of international nursing titles,68 as well as publications outlining international standards of classification for healthcare workers.69 To be included, studies must also identify specific pandemic roles, including but not limited to pandemic roles that were identified by primary care providers in our previously completed projects (ie, 3PC, 3PC-N; table 1).53 Studies must also describe any supports that facilitate the enactment of these roles; be based on empirical evidence (eg, quantitative, qualitative, analysis of health administration data); and examine findings from an OECD country.65 We will include articles written in English or French. No publication date restrictions will be applied to the search, as our goal is to examine the roles and supports for primary care providers during any historical pandemic period (eg, H1N1, SARS, etc).

caption.title: Family physicians’ pandemic roles and activities by pandemic stage in four regions in Canada53

tr.th: Family physicians’ pandemic roles and activities

tr.td: Provide leadership at clinic, institutional or regional levels
Implement infection prevention and control
Screen patients (active and passive screen)
Test patients or refer patients for testing
Advise patients on isolation/quarantine
Monitor COVID-19 patients recovering at home
Use special procedures to access supplies (swabs, personal protective equipment)
Educate patients about COVID-19 and infection control
Triage patients requiring in-person care
Modulate referrals to elective, specialist, surgical care; imaging, and/or lab testing
Use virtual and telephone visits
Direct patients to assessment centres/telephone triage lines
Staff assessment centres
Identify and support vulnerable patients (eg, frailty, addictions, etc)
Support travellers requiring screening/testing/isolation
Support community-based residential facilities experiencing outbreaks
Update care plans/goals for long-term care residents
Staff field hospitals or mobile health clinics
Assist with capacity in emergency departments, hospitals
Identify and support patients prioritised for vaccination
Address vaccine hesitancy
Staff vaccination centres and mobile clinics
Participate in evaluations of pandemic response

fn.p: Pandemic stages may not occur in a linear sequence and not all phases will occur in each region or pandemic. The phased closure and re-opening, acute care crisis and vaccination stages may overlap.

sec.p: We will limit the review to include only empirical studies with clear links between roles and supports, given the large number of commentaries which do not describe or evaluate actual supports in relation to pandemic roles. For the purposes of our review, we define pandemic roles as the specific tasks and/or responsibilities that primary care providers are expected to fulfil during the pandemic, but which are expected to stop once ‘normal’ operations resume.53 Roles may relate to modifications in the provisions of routine primary care and may vary by pandemic stage.53 We define supports as the policy instruments and/or infrastructure required by primary care providers to perform pandemic roles. Policy instruments can include exhortation, regulation, expenditure and public ownership and build on policies identified in our previously completed 3PC and 3PC-N projects (table 2).70

caption.title: Regulation, expenditure and public ownership policies* introduced to support family physicians in carrying out pandemic roles in four regions in Canada70

fn.p: Given the very large number of exhortation (defined as information only) policy-related documents during the COVID-19 pandemic, they were excluded from this table.

sec.title: Search strategy
sec.p: Working with a health sciences librarian, we developed a comprehensive search strategy to locate both published and unpublished literature (see online supplemental file 1). First, we developed a search strategy for the PubMed database (including MEDLINE) using controlled vocabulary terms (ie, Medical Subject Headings/MeSH) and relevant keywords (eg, ‘primary care’, ‘general practice’, ‘family physician’, ‘nurs*’, ‘health system response’, ‘pandemic plan*’). We then translated the PubMed strategy for use with additional databases, including CINAHL, Scopus and Embase (search conducted July 2025). Additional citations will be identified through a review of the reference lists of included articles and relevant systematic/scoping reviews that are identified during the search. We will conduct a separate search for grey (unpublished) literature using ProQuest Dissertations and Theses Global, Google Scholar and websites of other relevant research networks and national/international organisations (eg, Canadian Health Workforce Network, Primary and Integrated Healthcare Innovations Network, WHO, etc). We will also include relevant references from the 3PC and 3PC-N project publications.

sec.title: Study selection
sec.p: Following the search, we will collate and export all identified citations into Covidence software71 and remove duplicates. Prior to initiating screening, reviewers will discuss the title/abstract screening criteria to ensure there is a common understanding, and a pilot test will be carried out. During the pilot test, we will select a random sample of identified titles/abstracts and screen these against the selection criteria. A 75% agreement between reviewers in the pilot test will be required to initiate screening of the remaining articles. If there are any discrepancies or disagreements, we will update the selection criteria accordingly to increase clarity. After completion of the pilot test, two independent reviewers will screen each of the remaining titles and abstracts for eligibility. Following this, we will retrieve potentially relevant sources that meet the inclusion criteria in full and screen these against the selection criteria. At this stage, we will record reasons for the exclusion of studies. Disagreements between reviewers at any stage of the screening process will be resolved by an additional independent reviewer. Reviewers will also be encouraged to ask questions or clarify the screening criteria throughout all stages of the process to ensure there is a consistent and collective understanding.

sec.title: Data extraction
sec.p: Prior to the commencement of the data extraction stage, we will develop an extraction template in Covidence based on our nested logic model63 that addresses the three research questions. We will carry out a pilot test of the template, in which 3–5 articles will be randomly selected and extracted by two independent reviewers. If there are any concerns or discrepancies between reviewers, we will update or refine the extraction template to improve clarity and ensure that it is capturing data reflective of the research questions. Following this, two independent reviewers will extract each article, with one reviewer extracting the initial data, and a second reviewer checking the extracted responses, verifying accuracy and expanding on the initial extractor’s responses where necessary.

Extracted data will address the three research questions and include the following information: article details (eg, country where study was conducted, year of publication); study purpose and design; data collection details (eg, time period); study participants (eg, number and type of participants); study setting (eg, primary care clinic; COVID-19 assessment centre); type and description of study intervention (if applicable); descriptions of roles and corresponding supports; level of support (ie, clinic, community, regional or provincial levels); and the pandemic stage that each role and support corresponds with (ie, pre-pandemic, phased closure and re-opening, acute care crisis, vaccination, recovery)53.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: We will report the results of the search process in full and present this in a PRISMA-ScR flow diagram.67 Our primary outcome of interest is the roles carried out by primary care providers during a pandemic and the actual or proposed supports available to facilitate these roles. We will synthesise the data based on recurring themes and present this in summary tables,72 73 as well as frequency counts of specific roles/supports. Additionally, a narrative summary will be presented, describing how the results relate to the overarching objectives and identifying any knowledge gaps.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: The project will examine Middlesex County which includes the City of London (hereafter Middlesex-London) in Ontario, Canada. The county covers the service area of the Middlesex-London Health Unit (ie, public health) and includes primary care practices from Western University’s Department of Family Medicine and the Middlesex London Primary Care Network (a network of primary care providers that are part of the Middlesex-London Ontario Health Team). Middlesex-London has an estimated population of 530 000 residents living in urban (London), rural and three First Nations reserve communities. While the focus is on one region, the clinic-level, community-level and region-level plans can be adapted to other regions and feed into a province-level pandemic plan.

sec.title: Approach
sec.p: We will combine elements of a deliberative dialogue and a Delphi process74 75 to develop a list of priority supports for clinic-level, community-level and region-level pandemic plans in Middlesex-London, Ontario, Canada. Deliberative dialogues are intentional, facilitated discussions with stakeholders who have been purposefully invited for their specific perspectives and experiences.76 During these sessions, researchers provide participants with a synthesis of available evidence to inform the discussion,77 with a focus on generating ideas rather than achieving consensus.77 A Delphi process typically consists of three rounds of anonymised surveys in which participants rate or rank the relative importance of a range of options based on their personal opinions, experiences and preferences.75 Traditionally, these options are generated by participants, rather than being evidence-based; however, in the current project, the initial list of options will be informed by findings from the scoping review in objective 1 and further refined through participant input across the three Delphi process rounds. The ability to compare rankings by group characteristics (eg, urban vs rural, men vs women, public health vs primary care provider) will allow us to assess and incorporate equity considerations into the priority setting process.

sec.title: Recruitment and data collection
sec.p: The priority setting exercise will consist of a presentation and three rounds of online surveys using Qualtrics (Qualtrics, Provo, Utah, USA). Using convenience sampling, we will invite primary care providers (clinically active FPs, nurse practitioners, registered nurses and registered practical nurses), public health professionals (medical officers of health, public health physicians, public health nurses) and health system managers (heads of family medicine department clinical networks, hospital and regional government staff responsible for pandemic response), who work in Middlesex-London to participate in this exercise. We will exclude medical and nurse trainees. To recruit participants, we will ask the Department of Family Medicine at Western University (located in London, Ontario, Canada), the Middlesex London Primary Care Network and Primary Care Nurses of Ontario to email study invitations to providers. In addition, we will ask the Middlesex-London Health Unit and the London Health Sciences Centre to identify and send email invitations to relevant stakeholders. We will also invite FP and PCN participants from our two previous studies (ie, 3PC and 3PC-N) who work in Middlesex-London and members of Western University’s Centre for Studies in Family Medicine patient partner programme. To encourage participation, the presentation will be given at least two times; once as part of the Department of Family Medicine’s grand rounds or continuing professional education sessions, and once as an online presentation (ie, via Zoom). While there are no set sample sizes for a Delphi process,74 we estimate that 100 participants will attend the presentations and 60 will complete all three rounds of the survey. Invitations to the presentation will clearly state that participants can choose not to consent to the Delphi process surveys. To ensure we are gathering diverse opinions, we will aim to have a broad representation of participant groups (eg, primary care providers, public health professionals, health system managers) as well as variation across demographic characteristics (eg, gender, community size, etc).

In the presentation, we will share the results of the scoping review (objective 1), followed by a discussion and question-answer period. At the end of the session, we will share links to the first iteration of an online survey with participants (see online supplemental file 2). The first page of the survey in each round will provide information about the study and ask for consent. We estimate that each survey will take less than 15 min to complete. All surveys will be conducted online over approximately 6 weeks (1 week to complete the survey; 1 week to analyse results from each round). As per the Delphi process methodology, only participants who have completed the previous round will be invited to complete the subsequent rounds.74 To track respondents, we will ask participants to submit their email at the end of each round, which will be stored separately from survey responses to ensure confidentiality. To reduce attrition between rounds, we will send a $20 gift card to respondents who complete all three rounds.

In the first round, we will ask participants to provide demographic information (eg, gender, community size, professional group, presence of chronic illness, whether or not respondent has dependent/elder caregiving responsibilities) and then rank the relative importance of supports to include at clinic, community, regional and provincial levels using a 5-point Likert scale (where 1 is not important and 5 is extremely important). Participants will also be encouraged to provide open-ended comments to explain their rationale or suggest additional supports. Consensus to keep an item will be defined as 80% of participants rating it a 4 or higher on the Likert scale. In round two of the survey, we will summarise the results of round one, including comments, and ask participants to score any newly suggested items and any items with significant group differences. We will then repeat the process for round three.

sec.title: Analysis
sec.p: Using SPSS software (IBM SPSS Statistics V.28), we will conduct χ2 tests to compare scores throughout the three Delphi rounds by gender, profession, community size, presence of chronic illness and caregiving responsibility to identify potential group differences. Analysis for the final round will only include responses from participants who completed all three rounds. To assess potential bias, we will compare the characteristics and scores of participants who completed some versus all rounds of the survey. The final list of supports at each level will include items that met consensus by all respondents as well as additional items that met consensus by equity-deserving groups (ie, women, rural, caregiving or chronically ill respondents). We will present Likert scale data using descriptive statistics (eg, mean, range, SD) and provide summaries of demographic data.

sec.title: Approach
sec.p: We will establish working groups to co-create the development of clinic-level, community-level and region-level pandemic response plans for primary care led by primary care providers (clinic and community working groups) and public health (regional working group) members of the research team, additional members of the research team, stakeholders from Middlesex-London based on their experience and expertise (eg, from the Middlesex London Primary Care Network, Western University Department of Family Medicine, London Health Sciences Centre) and patient partners. Using convenience sampling, we will invite primary care providers (clinically active FPs, nurse practitioners, registered nurses and registered practical nurses), public health professionals (medical officers of health, public health physicians, public health nurses) and health system managers (heads of family medicine department clinical networks, hospital and regional government staff responsible for pandemic response), who work in Middlesex-London to participate in this exercise. We will exclude physician and nurse trainees. We will aim to engage approximately 12–24 participants across these groups.

Over the course of 1 year, the two working groups will attempt to operationalise the prioritised supports on their respective list and draft level-specific plans for each pandemic stage. Led by primary care providers and public health members of the research team, the working groups will work together to coordinate interdependent items and integrate the level-specific response plans. To encourage participation from community-based providers, such as FPs and PCNs, we will provide honoraria ($250/person) to those whose positions do not offer time for engaging in research (eg, FPs working in fee-for-service models).

Students (ie, Master of Public Health interns from Western University) and research assistants will support the working groups by preparing or collating guidance documents and procedures based on our archive of policy supports collated from the previous 3PC and 3PC-N projects (eg, guidance documents; pandemic response plans; examples of regulation, expenditure and public ownership policy supports) (table 2). They will also carry out rapid reviews as needed to inform the development and operationalisation of supports. Rapid reviews are systematic syntheses of the literature in which, because of truncated timelines, methods are streamlined and/or accelerated to inform decision-making.78 79

sec.title: Data collection and analysis
sec.p: Working groups will identify topics for rapid reviews (eg, the effectiveness of influenza-like clinics in diverting symptomatic patients away from family practices and emergency rooms) and clarify timelines. The research team will consult the working group to narrow the scope and define key elements of the review using either the PICO (population, intervention, comparator, outcome) or SPICE (setting, perspective, intervention, comparison, evaluation) formats78 and look for duplicate or similar existing reviews. Research assistants will review the results of the scoping review, as well as search a minimum of two electronic databases (eg, PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library) and selectively conduct targeted grey literature searches and reviews of reference lists. Reviewers will screen eligible studies, abstract data and conduct risk-of-bias assessments. Where applicable and possible, they will use the Grading of Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluation (GRADE) framework to assess the quality of evidence79 and produce a summary of studies and/or narrative (descriptive) synthesis.78 79

sec.title: Anticipated outcomes
sec.p: At the end of the plan creation objective of the project, we anticipate that the working groups will have operationalised some or all aspects of prioritised supports or will have decided not to operationalise a prioritised support. We also anticipate that the implementation of a support during a future pandemic may depend on further development or commitment decisions at higher levels. For example, a community-based PPE portal may depend on provincial funding and (along with the supports prioritised for the province-level) inform the development of the province-level pandemic response plan.

sec.title: Patient and public involvement
sec.p: Consistent with the view that practical problems are best defined by those who experience them,61 we will include individuals with lived experience (namely, primary care providers and public health professionals) in our research team and in all stages of the project. The priority-setting exercise and plan creation objectives will involve patient partners from Western University’s Centre for Studies in Family Medicine patient partner programme. All team members, including patient partners, will be invited to contribute to end-of-grant dissemination activities.

sec.title: Current study status
sec.p: At the time of writing (August 2025), we are completing screening and extraction of articles in the scoping review portion of the project (objective 1). The Delphi exercise (objective 2) will begin in October 2025. The plan creation phase (objective 3) will begin in spring 2026, with an estimated completion date of June 2027 for the full project.

sec.title: Ethics approval
sec.p: We have obtained formal ethics approval from the Western University Research Ethics Board (project ID: 127132). Throughout all objectives of this project, we will use best practices for promoting consent, confidentiality and data security.

sec.title: Knowledge translation and dissemination
sec.p: As part of an ongoing iKT plan, we will use a combination of video conferences (ie, via Zoom) and email for communications. We will engage with the primary care provider and public health community in Middlesex-London by inviting them to participate in the priority setting exercise and working groups. We will include decision-makers and knowledge user partner members of our research team throughout all stages of the project to ensure that their perspectives are integrated, and knowledge translation activities are responsive to real-world needs and priorities.

Our end-of-grant KT goals are to: (1) disseminate findings from the current project and previous projects (ie, 3PC, 3PC-N) with primary care providers and public health professionals in Middlesex-London; (2) disseminate pandemic plans for primary care and the model for creating them with primary care providers and public health professionals in Canada and internationally; (3) encourage further research related to emergency response preparedness and (4) raise public awareness of study findings. To achieve these goals, we will give presentations as part of the priority setting exercise; present at regional (eg, Trillium Primary Healthcare Research Day (Ontario), The Ontario Public Health Convention), national (eg, Family Medicine Forum, Canadian Association for Health Services and Policy Research, Canadian Public Health Association Conference) and international (eg, North American Primary Care Research Group, International Conference on Public Health) conferences and prepare articles for publication in peer-reviewed open access journals. Team members will also leverage their relationships with networks (eg, Council of Chief Medical Officers of Health, family medicine department heads, Ontario Health Team leads, Canadian Health Workforce Network, CANCOVID, Primary and Integrated Healthcare Innovations Network, regional health networks/zones) to disseminate study findings. We will also create a website to share a toolkit to help others develop pandemic plans for primary care in their regions. The toolkit will include the pandemic plans for primary care from Middlesex-London, a plain language summary of the scoping review, guidance for replicating the priority setting exercise and creating working groups, and examples of supports (eg, guidance documents, description of procedures, etc). To reach the public, we will write op-eds, prepare infographics, take part in media interviews, participate in online discussions (eg, healthydebate.ca) and use social media.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: This protocol has several limitations. First, the study’s focus on Southwestern Ontario may limit the applicability of findings to other regions with different demographic, healthcare and resource contexts; however, the toolkit we will develop aims to address this limitation by providing a replicable model that can be applied to different jurisdictions. Second, while our scoping review follows rigorous JBI methodology, it does not include formal critical appraisal of included studies, limiting the ability to assess quality of evidence. To mitigate this, we will focus on empirical literature with clearly defined links between primary care roles and supports, and we will use GRADE assessments in subsequent rapid reviews during plan creation (objective 3). Third, the Delphi process is geographically limited to participants in Middlesex-London, Ontario, which may affect the generalisability of findings; however, we will incorporate a diverse group of participants across roles, demographics and community contexts to support transferability. Lastly, pandemic preparedness can be influenced by policy shifts, differences in emerging infectious diseases and advancements in technology. As such, pandemic planning tools generated by this study may require periodic updates to remain relevant in future public health crises.

fn.p: Funding: This study is funded by a grant from the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (grant number: PPE 196084).
Prepublication history and additional supplemental material for this paper are available online. To view these files, please visit the journal online (https://doi.org/10.1136/bmjopen-2025-107804).
Provenance and peer review: Not commissioned; peer reviewed for ethical and funding approval prior to submission.
Patient consent for publication: Not applicable.

Patient and public involvement: Patients and/or the public were involved in the design, or conduct, or reporting, or dissemination plans of this research. Refer to the Methods section for further details.
